posts.name: Nathan S
posts.cooked:
To assist your friend with their school project, here's a concise description of how electric motors apply resistance during brake mode:

When a motor operates in brake mode, a resistive element is engaged to generate frictional force, thereby slowing the motor down. This mechanism ensures safe deceleration without abrupt stops, commonly utilizing series resistors or advanced flyback circuits depending on the motor type. Diagrams illustrating these braking systems typically show the resistor connected across the motor windings, forming a closed loop to dissipate mechanical energy effectively.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: The motor controller stops effectively when it's engaged in brake mode. While brushed and brushless motors differ slightly in their braking methods due to setup variations, both rely on proper wiring connections to function. Notably, Coast mode involves disengaging the wires entirely. For more details, consider reaching out to @jdao or @Wishbonea.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: When shorting both wires of a brushed motor, the motor experiences severe issues due to the sudden application of high current, leading to potential damage and operational reversals. In contrast, brushless motors maintain functionality by having redundant current paths, preventing such failures. This distinction is vital for efficient energy management, particularly in contexts like robotics competitions where energy redirection is essential.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
I did a lot of testing with a NEO a while back looking at all four quadrants of operation and braking mode. The motor is commanded to be at zero speed, brake mode is 100% shorted wires as discussed above. Itâ€™s better than two shorted wires! You must have all three shorted to simulate what a spark max is doing! I tested this too...

The situation is different when the motor is being told to drive at a speed and the shaft is doing something different from the command. This often happens when the robot is running fast and then is told to slow down/stop. In this case the way the three phase bridge works means the voltage generated by the motor is rectified back into the battery.

Also worth knowing, the current limit on a sparkmax doesnâ€™t work right in the overhauling quadrants; where the torque direction and the commanded direction donâ€™t match. It DOES work right in the two normal quadrants.

Brake mode continues to work when the robot is disabled. Brake mode does NOT work when the robot is turned off.
